messages.content: @tux-linux maybe we can keep the discussion about CI here
ok
For the record the idea is to have a gitea/gitlab instance on the new server and set up a CI worker that builds the images and publishes them for us
So we don't have to upload the full images and just push the updates to git

the thing is *I love hosting a Git server on a 20-year old thin client*
weeeell

*it makes it useful*
that is true
but yeah I understand what you mean
I'll try some stuff around and we can see if it works
And if it works well and you like it, well then
but if we have to switch, then we'll switch
I'm the same way with a lot of stuff so don't even worry hahaha
it'd be even better if we got a real Kobo port forwarded
that really would give it a purpose

we could say "Proudly hosted on a Kobo Glo HD"
people would be like *huh*
hahahaha
Hm... I'm sort of thinking...
This would be insane
BUT
And yes, it is totally insane
But a cool thing to do would be
only thing would be to hook up a real hard drive to it since SD cards wear out quickly
With the GitHub student pack you can get a full year of accomodation for a 1U server
what's that?
A rackable server
So you send the server and they put it in their datacenters
So if we get a 1U server case we could put inside some kobos and a couple more things
hahahhaha

a couple of emails later

well USBnetwork somehow
Then a wifi dongle to broadcast the signal to the kobos
Or usb, yeap
And some way to access it in case everything goes wrong hahahaha

yep
which is very likely to happen
I've seen some Kobos randomly rebooting when using Xorg, just they had no reason at all, they just decided to reboot because... well idk
well... you succeeded ;p
That sounds easy enough
I'm assuming you aren't currently building the images by hand, or that you're at least starting fresh each time

Yes, I'm currently building inkbox/kobox images by hand, and I (of course) start fresh every time, otherwise I would feel that it's not 'clean' or something like that...
The thing is that a lot of things get added over time and if I have some helper scripts to automatically create an update package for each device when I want to (it compresses, mksquashfs, openssl sign, etc.), some changes in the rootfs like X11 integration that will be out in v1.5 are incredibly difficult to put together for the upgrade to be actually seamless and to work.
I don't know if I'm quoting an existing citation, but I feel sometimes that the most difficult part in implementing new features in an OS like that is not developing them, but actually making the update package that the user will use.
Do you do it completely from scratch?
The updates or the images?
The builds
As in, no buildroot or anything

Boot process is as follows:
- Kernel
- Initrd (with busybox static binary for recovery purposes) which waits for a power button event, and if there is, "boots" to the second partition (recovery) by chrooting and mounting appropriate filesystems. (mmcblk0p2)
- Rootfs: Alpine 3.10 rootfs, fully bootable natively, but now I just chroot into it like the diags partition. (mmcblk0p3)
- Multiple chroots for various services: one for Xorg (Alpine 3.10), one for VNC/X11 touch input (Debian 8), and one for InkBox itself which runs a 2015 buildroot build since the glibc version supports the kernel correctly (2.6.35.3)
- Updates in the isa format are actually squashfs-compressed folders (usually in XZ, where possible) and are mounted via squashFUSE on boot. An extensions system for X11 allows seamless add/delete operations for extensions, e.g., netsurf.isa is an extension (which is like a mini root with the program and its deps), and the initrd detects it on boot and merges it (unionfs-fuse) with the main X.org rootfs, also a Squashfs, but overlayfs-fuse mounted so it can be writeable.

I hope I did not lose you...
Have you considered using namespaces rather than chroots?
Squashfs is nice
You don't need FUSE for it, though
Haven't ever heard of it lol...
Yes, because 2.6.35.3 kernel doesn't support XZ compressed ones
So FUSE became handy
Extensions remind me of systemd extensions
to grasp a better undestanding of the mount process, maybe...
But based on what you said, your layout is more like Nix or Gobo
Oh, you use overlayfs
yes, it's a giant mess of squashfuse, unionfs and overlayfs

but the initrd does its job and it works better than I expected
like, just drag'n'drop the extension and the contents of it gets merged automatically at next boot
Yep
Note that you're pretty much on the path to reimplementing containers or reimplementing nixos
the drawing was actually for me to undestand how to do it ;p
A container runtime would probably be too heavy, though, so you'd probably want to continue doing it manually
You might want to consider using nixos as a base, though

That's `df -h`, just looks awful
```
kobo:/home/user# df -h
Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/mmcblk0p3  2.9G  2.0G  751M  73% /
/dev/mmcblk0p1   29M  2.9M   25M  11% /boot
/dev/loop7      1.0M  1.0M     0 100% /opt/root
/dev/loop6      1.0M  1.0M     0 100% /opt/key
devtmpfs         10M     0   10M   0% /dev
tmpfs           125M   12K  125M   1% /tmp
squashfuse       52M   52M     0 100% /opt/X11/base/rootfs
squashfuse      102M  102M     0 100% /opt/X11/vnc-touch
squashfuse       11M   11M     0 100% /opt/X11/extensions/adwaita-icons
squashfuse       11M   11M     0 100% /opt/X11/extensions/netsurf
squashfuse       61M   61M     0 100% /opt/X11/extensions/python3-onboard
squashfuse      2.0M  2.0M     0 100% /opt/X11/extensions/ssh
unionfs          84M   84M     0 100% /opt/X11/extensions/merged
unionfs         136M  136M     0 100% /opt/X11/merged
fuse-overlayfs  2.9G  2.0G  751M  73% /xorg
tmpfs           125M     0  125M   0% /xorg/tmp
tmpfs           125M     0  125M   0% /xorg/run
tmpfs           125M     0  125M   0% /xorg/dev/shm
tmpfs           125M     0  125M   0% /opt/X11/vnc-touch/tmp
tmpfs           125M     0  125M   0% /opt/X11/vnc-touch/run
tmpfs           125M     0  125M   0% /opt/X11/vnc-touch/dev/shm
tmpfs            25M   68K   25M   1% /run
shm             125M     0  125M   0% /dev/shm
/dev/loop0      253M  8.1M  244M   4% /kobo/mnt/onboard/onboard
squashfuse       75M   75M     0 100% /opt/isa
squashfuse       11M   11M     0 100% /kobo/mnt/onboard/.adds/inkbox
squashfuse       35M   35M     0 100% /kobo/mnt/onboard/.adds/qt-linux-5.15.2-kobo
squashfuse       31M   31M     0 100% /kobo/mnt/onboard/.adds/Python-3.9.2
tmpfs           125M   16K  125M   1% /kobo/tmp
tmpfs           125M     0  125M   0% /kobo/run
tmpfs           125M     0  125M   0% /kobo/inkbox
kobo:/home/user# 
```
I'll look into it
Not too bad, but beware of the overhead from all the FUSE layers
And if not, at least use some ideas from it
What does that do?
FUSE requires a lot of userspace copying and context switching
Oh, and if you want to do everything manually
Well, idle, CPU is at ~1.3% of usage
The first thing I suggest you work on is a packaging tool which has an input similar to Alpine or Arch
I'm mostly talking about overhead for many small writes/reads, or for large writes through multiple layers
Ah ok
Packaging tool; you mean something to "package" the rootfs? or the extensions?
`apk` sure is very handy when I need some quick native compilation
The extensions
Ah
The rootfs will come naturally from that
Well, currently, I `apk fetch` the packages (they're tar archives), then untar all of them in a directory, then mksquashfs and there you go

Also, not that I'm in a desperate need of testers, but I saw you had a Mini, feel free to test InkBox on it if you have time (and if you want, of course)! 

You can also enable USBNet for SSH root access (after factory reset--allow root, then Diags -> Flags -> Enable USBNet), and the Kobo's IP will be 192.168.2.2

Hi, maybe this is not the best place to ask this, but I think you would know that better than anyone else. Currently I have a clara HD with original soft, battery is discharging unconsistently when it's not in use. I rode somewhere that cases that turn on the screen can be a source of problems. The question is, you know any way of log this screen on events? If I see that multiple screen on occurs while I'm sleeping that will be the problem for sure.
Aditional info, it can be one day to other at 80%, I read till 78%, well, the next day randomly it can be at 78% or 50%. Wifi is off all the time.
What do you mean by "screen on events"?
I would like to log when the screen is turned on, or the magnetic switch for the case
when the device wakes from sleep?
Yes
Maybe is it already logged by Nickel
Let me check
Sorry if I don't explain well on english
Thank you very much
But I don't use nickle apps :( is that a problem?
you're using koreader?
No, just default reader
that is nickel
The os that comes with kobo after buy it is nickel?
yeah
Well, Nickel is the binary that contains the main UI
Thats great
There's also `pickel`, `sickel`, `hindenburg`, etc.
plus some standard Linux utilities
So I can check times the screen wakes from sleep using ssh?
That's what I'm trying to see right now
Thanks
Actually, you can't directly

But if you look in `dmesg` for messages like this:
```PM: resume of devices complete after 361.239 msecs
PM: Finishing wakeup.```
That tells you the device has finished waking from sleep
Or, if you connect to Wi-Fi, you can check when `dhcpcd` restarts itself. But that is less precise, since Nickel can disable Wi-Fi too
Wow I think the dmesg is what I was looking for
But dmesg gets overwritten at some point
by other useless things
Doing grep on that could check some wakeups
Running `klogd` first will send it to the syslog, which you can read with `logread`
That'll net you timestamps, which are generally helpful
oh
that's awesome
Keep in mind that the PM stuff may actually be logged only on *resume*
I think it's what he wants to know
So, caveat emptor for this particular bit of messaging
